items.title: python-magic for android
items.body:
I'm building a bulldozer app for Android, written in kivy. In it, I need to import a python-magic library that can define the MIME type. When debugging my app via logcat this exception occurs:

> 07-05 16:53:56.210 26146 26333 I python  :  Traceback (most recent call last):
07-05 16:53:56.211 26146 26333 I python  :    File "/home/user/TestKivyMd/.buildozer/android/app/main.py", line 13, in <module>
07-05 16:53:56.211 26146 26333 I python  :    File "/home/user/TestKivyMd/.buildozer/android/app/file_manager.py", line 5, in <module>
07-05 16:53:56.211 26146 26333 I python  :    File "/home/user/TestKivyMd/.buildozer/android/platform/build-armeabi-v7a/build/python-installs/myapp/magic.py", line 201, in <module>
07-05 16:53:56.212 26146 26333 I python  :  ImportError: failed to find libmagic.  Check your installation

This exception probably occurs in this piece of python-magic library code:
```
libmagic = None
# Let's try to find magic or magic1
dll = ctypes.util.find_library('magic') \
    or ctypes.util.find_library('magic1') \
    or ctypes.util.find_library('cygmagic-1') \
    or ctypes.util.find_library('libmagic-1') \
    or ctypes.util.find_library('msys-magic-1') #for MSYS2

# necessary because find_library returns None if it doesn't find the library
if dll:
    libmagic = ctypes.CDLL(dll)

if not libmagic or not libmagic._name:
    windows_dlls = ['magic1.dll', 'cygmagic-1.dll', 'libmagic-1.dll', 'msys-magic-1.dll']
    platform_to_lib = {'darwin': ['/opt/local/lib/libmagic.dylib',
                                  '/usr/local/lib/libmagic.dylib'] +
                       # Assumes there will only be one version installed
                       glob.glob('/usr/local/Cellar/libmagic/*/lib/libmagic.dylib'),  # flake8:noqa
                       'win32': windows_dlls,
                       'cygwin': windows_dlls,
                       'linux': ['libmagic.so.1'],  # fallback for some Linuxes (e.g. Alpine) where library search does not work # flake8:noqa
                      }
    platform = 'linux' if sys.platform.startswith('linux') else sys.platform
    for dll in platform_to_lib.get(platform, []):
        try:
            libmagic = ctypes.CDLL(dll)
            break
        except OSError:
            pass

if not libmagic or not libmagic._name:
    # It is better to raise an ImportError since we are importing magic module
    raise ImportError('failed to find libmagic.  Check your installation')

```
The problem is that python-magic defines android as linux. But android doesn't have a built-in magic library.
Everything works fine on XUbuntu 18.04. How can I fix this problem?

items.title: Expose libmagic.magic_version
items.body:
We recently ran into an issue where versions of `libmagic` older than 1.35 did not detect JSON files (and some of our systems had out of date libmagic installs).

The [`magic_version`](https://github.com/file/file/blob/56367e2bbd0d01601a8875879d73cfd652d7206a/src/magic.c#L586) method in libmagic gives an integer for the version number. I believe it could be exposed in the package as `magic.magic_version` in a way similar to [`magic_open`](https://github.com/ahupp/python-magic/blob/4e415a1c1cc5a874e213d1ea02d3050f7d57b8fe/magic.py#L248-L250). We used `magic.libmagic.magic_version` and it worked, but it is probably better to have it properly exposed in the python package.

The package could also have a slightly more complex method to yield a version number using one of the two version classes from [`distutils.version`](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.8/Lib/distutils/version.py), just to make it nicer than an integer.

items.title: Warning when importing magic from latest python3.8
items.body:
Hello,

When importing magic using the latest python3.8, it produces a warning:
```
Python 3.8.0a2+ (heads/master:ed1deb0, Feb 27 2019, 09:39:58) 
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import magic
/home/gabriel/Projects/python-magic/magic.py:203: SyntaxWarning: "is" with a literal. Did you mean "=="?
  if result is -1:
>>> 
```
It seems that this warning has been introduced in  2019-Jan-17 with this commit:
[https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/3bcbedc9f1471d957a30a90f9d1251516b422416](https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/3bcbedc9f1471d957a30a90f9d1251516b422416)

I did a quick fix for this issue, which removes the warning and no other warning remains:

```
diff --git a/magic.py b/magic.py
index d027157..bd9d6b4 100644
--- a/magic.py
+++ b/magic.py
@@ -200,7 +200,7 @@ def errorcheck_null(result, func, args):
 
 
 def errorcheck_negative_one(result, func, args):
-    if result is -1:
+    if result == -1:
         err = magic_error(args[0])
         raise MagicException(err)
     else:
```

Regards,
Gabriel

items.title: No changelog
items.body:
## Description of the issue

StegoVeritas uses python-magic as a dependency. Something broke with python-magic, but since python-magic have no changelog (either a separate file or in the github release history) it is impossible to say if an update in python-magic introduced a breaking change.

## Way to solve

Use a changelog where all version release are documented

## Reference

https://github.com/bannsec/stegoVeritas/issues/10

items.title: Test suite breakage with recent file/libmagic version
items.body:
As reported in <https://bugs.debian.org/897471>, the python-magic test suite breaks when handling "test.gz". The actual reason is in libmagic - it required some digging to understand magic_file() on a file name and magic_buffer on a buffer loaded from that particular file may return a different result, just because the first is a file.

magic_file() result:
gzip compressed data, was "test", last modified: Sun Jun 29 01:32:52 2008, from Unix, original size 15

magic_buffer result:
gzip compressed data, was "test", last modified: Sun Jun 29 01:32:52 2008, from Unix


At first, it would have been easier to find this if test.py would have reported a difference in the first place. Perhaps something like the following?

@@ -26,6 +26,11 @@ class MagicTest(unittest.TestCase):
                     buf_value = m.from_buffer(f.read())
 
                 file_value = m.from_file(filename)
+                if buf_value != file_value:
+                    print("from_buffer: '" + buf_value + "'")
+                    print("from_file:   '" + file_value + "'")
+                    self.assertTrue(False, "from_buffer from_file output mismatch")
+                    break


Also, for the time being I suggest to disable that particular test, or to work around it in a sane way. Also, don't forget to add the new output to the list of possible results.

Regards,

    Christoph

items.title: testing with test.py at present works only from parent directory -- suggested patch
items.body:
The python test script test.py which is invoked from run.sh can only be successfully run at present if the current directory is the parent directory of test due to the use of relative paths and even hardcoded string paths in test.py.  Furthermore the test of byte representations of file names is only done in Python 3 because the "b" operator is ignored in Python 2 (according to what I have read after much web searching).

Hopefully my replacement of filename.encode as recommended by "agf" at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7585435/best-way-to-convert-string-to-bytes-in-python-3 provides the necessary equivalent.

I therefore suggest the following changes to test.py which result in the script being executed correctly regardless of the current directory eg even from the test directory its-self in which some people (myself included) first try to run the run.sh script rather than its parent directory.

patch to test/test.py to allow it to be executed independent of current directory:
[test.py.patch.txt](https://github.com/ahupp/python-magic/files/2087322/test.py.patch.txt)

Patch is against current "latest" python-magic revision 3ca9548

items.title: Suggestion for an improved test run.sh test script (script attached)
items.body:
The current test run.sh test script tries to run python executables even if they are not available and the script is not flexible for testing multiple versions of python if they are available.

Please find attached a suggestion for an improved shell script for which testing against officially supported versions can easily be changed by editing the values of the variables PYTHON2_VERSIONS and PYTHON3_VERSIONS, and which also tests against major version numbers for completeness.

The test for each version is only run if the python version is found in the current ${PATH} environmental variable which is checked by means of the Bourne shell "command" builtin + "-v" option.

suggested improved test/run.sh Bourne shell script:
[run.sh.txt](https://github.com/ahupp/python-magic/files/2087310/run.sh.txt)

items.title: Please exempt "magic.pyc" test file from cleaning, or rename it
items.body:
Hello,

the test data directory contains a file "magic.pyc". Some build systems run "clean" on the source tree, and compiled python files are removed during such an operation - which in general is the right thing but undesired here since subsequently the test suite will fail for a missing file.

Please find a solution for this - either by signalling this file shall be exempted from clean, if possible. Or by renaming it. The latter is certainly easier to do.

items.title: CPU loop (Python 2.7.8 on Windows 7 and 10)
items.body:
I initially encountered this as an [apparent issue with eyed3](https://github.com/nicfit/eyeD3/issues/84), but have been able to isolate it to magic, which is used by eyed3.

Python script calling magic is non-responsive, even to a CTRL-C; Process Explorer sees CPU to the python task go to nearly 25% (i.e., one core).

Simple script to reproduce:

```Python
import sys
print "OS info:\n ", sys.getwindowsversion()
print "Python info:\n ", sys.version
import magic
print "Calling magic..."
print magic.from_file("test.py")
print "returned from magic call."
```

Output:
```
OS info:
  sys.getwindowsversion(major=6, minor=1, build=7601, platform=2, service_pack='Service Pack 1')
Python info:
  2.7.8 (default, Jul  2 2014, 19:50:44) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)]
Calling magic...
```
... at which point the script hangs, pegging CPU at ~25% (one of four cores), the call never completing. I can kill the Python task from Process Explorer.

based on some print statements, it appears to be hanging in ```class Magic```, ```__init__```, at the statement
```Python
self.cookie = magic_open(self.flags)
```

items.title: No wheel for latest version 0.4.12
items.body: This project has `bdist_wheel` configuration in its `setup.cfg` but no wheel has been published. This implies that the `bdist_wheel` step was missed in release. A full sdist + bdist_wheel release can be done with `python setup.py clean sdist bdist_wheel upload`. You can also upload the wheel right now by checking out the source code at the version for the last release and running `python setup.py clean bdist_wheel upload`. This will speed up everyone's installs 🐇 😄

items.title: magic.from_buffer() swallows errors
items.body:
Using libmagic version 5.26 (Macports libmagic@5.26_0) the following happens

``` python
import magic
magic.from_buffer(b'<?xml version="1.0"?>', mime=True) is None  # -> True
```

In this `magic._magic_buffer` returns `None` which is recognized by `magic.errorcheck_null` which raises `magic.MagicException(b'Offset out of range')`. The try/except and the condition in `_handle509Bug` result in the exception to be ignored and `None` to be returned.

Is returning `None` the desired behavior or should a) the exception be allowed to propagate or b) an unconditional fallback value (`application/octet-stream`) be used instead? I'd prefer the public API to provide the means to handle and understand specific error conditions.

FWIW, I'm using Python version

```
3.5.1 (default, Mar  2 2016, 03:38:02)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 7.0.2 (clang-700.1.81)]
```

items.title: I'm the Gentoo maintainer for eyeD3 (python)
items.body:
I'm the Gentoo maintainer for eyeD3 python module:
http://eyed3.nicfit.net/
It seems that the new 0.7.4 version uses this python-magic module which is in fact a direct conflict with the python-magic version that has been a stable API for years, file-5.17's magic.py:
http://www.darwinsys.com/file/
so now some packages can no longer co-exist on the same system:
https://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=488270

While this project is still young, can you please rename the library, to, for example, magic2 as to imply this is the continuity of the prev. library if you are in fact sure the magic.py from _the_ file package that is installed on every _nix system is obsolete/no longer maintained, which is suspect it's not
I don't remember seeing any bugs about it, only use:
https://github.com/pazz/alot (alot mail client uses file's magic.py)
http://code.google.com/p/binwalk/ (tool identifying files embedded inside firmware images also uses file's magic)
Sabayon Linux distributions *package manager_ equo uses file's magic.py:
http://www.sabayon.org

Please :)

items.body:
I have some files that are causing a MagicException to be thrown with no details.  This is on Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, with all packages up to date, and using the latest version of python-magic installed with pip. 

Stack trace is below.  I have stepped through the code, and it appears that it's dying somewhere in the ctypes error handler:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test_magic.py", line 35, in <module>
    mime_type = magic.from_file(filename, mime=True)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/magic.py", line 121, in from_file

  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/magic.py", line 169, in errorcheck_null

I used the Python debugger, and in the errorcheck_null() method, the "result" parameter is "None", the "func" argument has a dict with "**name**==magic_file", and the "args" argument is a tuple with the numeric value 22135440 and the filename of the file I'm checking.

Since this is Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, the Python version is 2.7.3 (2.7.3-0ubuntu3.4) and the libmagic1 version is 5.09-2.  I have been unable to reproduce this issue on Ubuntu 13.04 or Ubuntu 13.10, so I think it's something specific to either Python 2.7.3 or the version of libmagic1.  Unfortunately I don't have the luxury of upgrading the Ubuntu version, since this is for a commercial production use.

What does the numeric value 22135440 mean?  I realize that this may be a bug with either Python or libmagic1, but I'm not sure what the issue is to report it.

items.title: Unicode file name issue on windows
items.body:
This is the same as https://github.com/ahupp/python-magic/issues/9
BUT I cannot encode to utf-8 as I do not know which encoding was used to create that filename. The file was created on some linux and is extracted on windows.

A test file is in this archive: https://github.com/pombredanne/python-magic/blob/issue_42/testdata/a.zip

When extracted on windows I can os.walk or os.listdir(u'some dir') (using a unicode string for the input dir) where this file has been extracted and open the file in Python alright. ie os.path.exists is True and the file can be opened.

Yet magic.from_file fails when passing the filename whether as a string or unicode

The point being that you cannot rely on my file system encoding to convert the file name, because it was created elsewhere, and the encoding is arbitrary, eventually unknown.

The best explanation of the problem is here IMHO: http://web.archive.org/web/20081219193532/http://boodebr.org/main/python/all-about-python-and-unicode#UNI_FILENAMES

NB: FWIW, I cannot get run the file command line to work on that path either... so it could be a problem with the file code itself, not your ctypes wrapper

items.title: brew file-formula isn't the valid formula anymore...?
items.body:
FYI, homebrew seems to have renamed the file-formula package.

```
$ brew --version
0.9.4

Based on [this URL](http://www.brambraakman.com/blog/comments/installing_libmagic_in_mac_os_x_for_python-magic/) you now have to brew `libmagic` instead.  Note that I did not have to create the symbolic as that article suggest towards the end.
